Anna lives in Norashen village with her husband, mother-in-law, son and daughter. Anna and her husband run a farm, where they grow different types of fruit trees (peach, apricot, plum, granate, walnut, apple, pear) and keep hens. They have been involved in agriculture for 15 years. The main source of income for Anna is selling the harvest in local markets. She also keeps a freezer, where she keeps the fruits to sell during winter. 

As for the main part of the harvest from the orchard, Anna sells it after gathering it. She would like to purchase more fruits to keep in the freezer. With the loan's help, she will purchase four tons of pears, three tons of peaches and one ton of persimmons. This allows Anna to have stable income all year, which is vital for her to cover her household costs and children's educational costs.

loans.use: to pay for peaches, pears and persimmons to keep in the freezer to sell in winter.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is a vegetable farmer in Ndunyu Njeru town and sells vegetables to various customers in the market. She is 42 years old, married to James, and they have two children.

This is her second loan amount, and she plans to use the amount to boost her vegetable business by buying vegetable seeds for planting. These seeds include spinach, carrots and kale. With the anticipated income, she will pay school fees for her children.

In the future, she hopes to grow her business and make more income.

loans.use: to boost her vegetable business.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George, a 31-year-old father of one child aged six years, is a mixed farmer in Olkalau town. He keeps dairy cows and also plants cash crops for selling. He is married to Regina, who is also a farmer.

This is his third loan term with KADET LTD, and he plans to use this loan amount to buy a dairy cow. This will enable him to increase his milk production as well as make more income.

George hopes to improve his farming methods and make more income so as to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Gilford

texts.en:
Gilford is a farmer in Olkalau town and has been in the business for twelve years. He is 64 years old, married to Sabella, and they have three children who are in school.

This is his third loan and he plans to use the amount to pay school fees for his children who are in college and high school.

He hopes to improve his farming methods by planting in large scale and make more income, hence be able to provide good education for his children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Laban

texts.en:
Laban used his previous loan to buy goods for sell in his retail shop. It was profitable and he paid all the loan amount. Besides the retail shop business, he is also a dairy farmer and supplies milk to his customers.

This being his second loan amount, he plans to buy a motorcycle for transport business. He will also use the motorcycle to supply milk to his customers within the area and also those who are far.

He hopes to grow all his businesses and make more income,hence be able to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is taking out a new loan in order to expand on the existing business. He is so grateful for the support he is getting; he was able to purchase stock in a large quantity. He says that his family's living standards have also improved.

Emmanuel plans to buy more stock of charcoal to meet his ever-increasing customer demands. His aim is to own a charcoal depot and improve his home.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius has been a farmer in Olkalau town where he practices dairy farming as well as plants cash crops, such as maize and beans for selling. He has previously taken loans from KADET LTD, and it has been profitable to his business. Besides farming he also has a timber yard business.

This is his fourth loan term, and he plans to use the amount to buy seeds and fertilizer for planting. He also plans to buy timber for selling in his timber yard business. With the anticipated income, he will pay school fees for his children.

Julius hopes to expand both his businesses, make more income, and improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy seeds & fertilizer and timber.

loans.name: Ma.marilyn

texts.en:
Ma.Marilyn is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children. 

Ma.Marilyn makes and sells fish balls and lumpia. She has had this business for 7 years. She requested a loan of 4,000 PHP to buy raw ingredients to make fish balls and lumpia, like fresh fish, flour and spices.

Ma.Marilyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients to make fish balls and lumpia

loans.name: Arnelyn

texts.en: Arnelyn is married and has 2 children. She is 27 years old and lives in Guba, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She cultivates mangoes and plants vegetables (particularly eggplant) to earn a living and has had this business for 7 years. Each month, she earns about PHP 6,700 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 10,000 to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She's been a member of GDMPC since 2011. In the future, Arnelyn hopes to improve her business so that she can have her own store.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen is a 40-year-old hard working woman, living in Punjab, Pakistan with her two sons and husband . Her husband works as a salesman in a general store. All of her children are school students. She herself has been running a beauty salon for 2 years. 

Perveen, as a member of a five-person lending group, has requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan. With the loan amount, she will be purchasing some chairs and cosmetic products for her beauty salon.  As she is living in a rented house with her family, she dreams to build her own house. She also desires to increase her business and dreams of giving her children a quality education.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and cosmetic products for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Radisa

texts.en: Radesa is married with two children. She is 37 years old and lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Radesa cultivates coconuts for a living and has had this business for 12 years. Each month, she earns PHP 6,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to pay for services in farm maintenance. Radesa has been a member of GDMPC since 2011. In the future, Radesa hope to improve her small business so that she can build her own house.

loans.use: to pay for services in farm maintenance

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stock of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
This is Alma. She previously accessed a 22,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial growth with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Alma hopes to give her children a good quality education and dreams to have a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her businesses.

loans.name: Lyn

texts.en:
Bahati sells clothing, a business in which she has an experience of three years. She is happy to have a second child, but she struggles to provide for the children. Bahati sells a variety of used clothing ranging from men's to children's clothes.

She is now requesting a new loan to buy several bales of used clothing. With the support of this loan, she will be able to stock her store with new styles so that all of her customers can sport the latest fashions. She appreciates the previous loan which helped her to improve her income.

Her goal is to have a larger business in the downtown core of the city in order to have a greater influx of customers. This is her second loan with Yehu and she hopes to repay her loan punctually.

loans.use: to buy several bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a variety of fish to resell.

loans.name: Marribel

texts.en:
Marribel is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her food vending business.

Marribel has been in this business for one year. Marribel earns more income from a general store.

Marribel has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Mwenda

texts.en:
Mwenda is 35 years old, married, mother of five children.  She has earned a living by selling milk in Malindi for the last five years.  Mwenda earns a monthly profit of KES. 9,000.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our credit officers, and is applying for her first loan of KES. 10,000, to buy dairy equipment such as milk cans, milking gloves, water cans for the cows to drink from and so on for her business. 

Mwenda will use the anticipated profits made from this loan to pay for her children's school fees and to expand her farming activities. 

Her goal for the future is to venture into mixed farming with a view of increasing her income in order to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy dairy equipment.

loans.name: Claris

texts.en:
Claris is married and living with her spouse and their two school going children in a rental house in the city of Mombasa. 

She’s a very hardworking and honest woman who has been selling charcoal for the past two years.  Claris wants to continue helping her husband with household expenses. 

Claris says that when she started out she used to sell one sack of charcoal, but thanks for her determination she can now buy several sacks. 

Claris is requesting the loan to expand her business by purchasing more sacks of charcoal.  This will help her meet customer demands and increase daily sales and thereby help her family. 

Her dream is to have her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fish to resell.

loans.name: Bahtishahe

texts.en:
Bahtishahe is thirty-six years old. She is married and has five children between the ages of three to seventeen years old. She is a seamstress and lives in the south-western part of Kosovo with her children. Her husband works in Italy to support his family.

Bahtishahe and her husband love her children very much and she loves taking care of them. They are both trying to make good conditions for them. 
Her family has had a longstanding problem with their bathroom. The money they generate is not enough to pay for repairing the bathroom. For the first time she is requesting a 500 EUR loan to buy a water heater and other essential parts for renovating and repairing the bathroom.  She hopes that this loan will improve the health of her family and their living conditions, which is her goal. 

Bahtishahe is very grateful to the Kiva lenders for contributing and assisting her family in obtaining these improved conditions.

loans.use: To buy a water heater and other essential parts for renovating and repairing the bathroom

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie is 44 years old, married with two adult-age and four school-age children.  

She's run an eatery business for a year and has a monthly income of Php 4,500.  

Jessie decided to become part of PMPC to support her business.  She took a loan to purchase fish, meat and spices to make a variety of viands (food items).   She plans to use the profit to invest more capital in to her business, support the educational needs of the children and to save.

loans.use: to purchase fish, meat and spices.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma works hard to support her family.  She is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Alma requested a PHP 12000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her business.  She has run her food vending business for four years.

In the future, Alma would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Bashiran

texts.en:
Bashiran is a 57-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store in her community for the last five years. She offers various goods for daily use. She has good communication skills and counts on a good client list. Her husband is employed in a security guard firm and earns insufficient income to support his family alone. 

She is the mother of three children. She is motivated to provide for her family. As she wants to grow her business, she requested a loan of Rs 20,000 to buy rice, children's sweets, flour, etc. from the market at lower rates. She then would be able to meet the increasing demand consistently. She is in her 2nd loan cycle and has shown excellent repayment behavior. She wishes to utilize part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses and to increase business capital.

loans.use: To buy rice, children's sweets, flour, etc.

loans.name: Anthony Jerry

texts.en:
This is Anthony. He previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that he utilized to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in his business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan for he will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to his inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain their daily needs and the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Anthony hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of giving his children a good and quality education. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of his work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and other products to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan lives in Nor Dvin village with her husband, son and mother-in-law.   Her husband leaves for work abroad to help sustain his family.  Her son serves in the army. 

Susan runs a farm, where she breeds pigs, cultivates potato and grows peach and apricot trees.  She would like to start breeding cows and earn more income from agriculture.  This is why she has applied for this loan; to purchase two calves, forage and grass to feed them. 

Susan hopes she will develop her agriculture business and earn enough income for her family, which will allow her husband to stay with her and her family and get involved in agriculture, too.

loans.use: to purchase two calves, forage and grass to feed them.

location.town: Nor Dvin village of Ararat region

loans.name: Recho

texts.en:
Recho is 38 years old and married with five children. She has been in the cereal business for the last eight years, earning approximately 20,000 KES monthly. 

This loan of 20,000 KES is her first loan from KADET LTD, and she plans to use it to purchase six bags of dry beans for resale. 

Recho plans to put her anticipated profit toward loan repayment, and will save the rest to buy a grinding mill. She hopes to open a grinding mill to earn additional income, so she can educate and provide for her children.

loans.use: to purchase six bags of dry beans to resell.

loans.name: Flermina

texts.en: Flermina is a dedicated woman of high integrity. She always finds opportunities for her to prosper. She has been operating a beauty salon for over five years, which she is still running. Flermina has seen the importance of Yehu and Kiva loans. This is why she has turned to Yehu to ask for another loan of KES 30,000. She says that the previous loan helped her make improvements in her salon. This is her fifth loan from Yehu. She plans to purchase a blow dryer and a dryer, and some other beauty chemicals. With these investments, she is sure to provide better services to her customers.

loans.use: to purchase a blow dryer and a drier, and some other beauty chemicals.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: Mavluda is 18 years old. She is not married and lives with her parents. Mavluda wants to have her own business deal. She decided to start a new business with sewing national women's dresses in order to generate an income with which she can contribute to her home’s finances. She studied the course of ‘To get ahead’ with a women's organization and got enough skills about business. She will be very a successful business woman as she is hardworking and smart. She is asking for a loan of 5,000 somoni to buy a sewing machine for organizing her new business. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine for organizing a new business.

loans.name: Clemencia

texts.en:
This is Clemencia. She previously accessed an 18,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her family’s daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Clemencia hopes her business grows and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week; this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Babeth

texts.en: Babeth is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. Babeth has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that buys and sells canned goods, snacks, personal-care products, home-use products, and beverages. She has had this business for 7 years. She requested a loan for  5,000 PHP to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages. Babeth has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, Babeth hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida works hard to support her family. Nida is married and has a business selling used clothing in the Philippines.

Nida requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to purchase more used clothing to sell.

Nida has been in this business for 5 years now and also earns additional income from sari-sari store.

In the future, Nida would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothing to sell.

loans.name: Felma

texts.en: Felma is a micro-finance member of PMPC.  She is 58 years old and is married with 3 adult-age children.  She lives in Candanay Norte, Siquijor, Siquijor. She is engaged in making rice cakes for sale.  She has operated the business for over 20 years having a monthly average earnings of PHP 1,500.  She took a loan in PMPC to purchase raw ingredients to make rice cakes.  She hopes to improve the living conditions of the family and to be able to save for the future.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make rice cakes

loans.name: Najma

texts.en: Ms Najma had a difficult time after her husband's business failure. She decided to work with her husband and to support her family for a better future. 18 years ago she began doing stitching work in her house. She stitches for the people living around her house and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to the lack of availability of funds she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. She is married and provides for 5 children. She is currently in her 2nd loan cycle and has borrowed Rs 25,000 from Kashf. She intents to use this loan amount to buy raw material including cloth, threads of different colors, laces, zippers, etc., to create a means of increasing revenue so she may be able to generate a healthier source of income.

loans.use: to buy raw material including cloth, threads of different colors, laces, zippers, etc.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
This is George. He previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that he utilized to purchase additional stock of mineral water and LPG tanks needed in his business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in their personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan that he will use to pay for additional stock of mineral water and LPG tanks needed in his business. More items to sell will result in better profit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his family's daily needs and the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

George hopes that his business will continue to be successful and dreams to give his children a good and quality education. He faithfully meets with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God he studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stock of mineral water and LPG tanks needed in his business.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Ms. Safia is a hardworking, devoted woman. After her marriage and having 4 children, she soon realized that she also had to contribute to the earnings of the family. 10 years ago she started a business which does not require much of a capital and yet it had the capacity to substantially increase in the earnings of the family. She started a book binding business. Initially she took much time in binding a book but as time has passed by her speed of binding the books has increased and she is able to get the orders of her community. She is famous amongst the children of the community as she binds their old books and she is polite to them. 

Currently she is taking her 4th loan from Kashf and her payment record is excellent. As she binds the book of others so it is her deep wish that her children reach higher education and reach the high posts in their service. With the 20,000 PKR loan, she is now able to purchase more hot melt glue, mull cloth, PVC Coated paper and shrink film so that she is able to meet the increasing demand of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more hot melt glue, mull cloth, PVC Coated paper, and shrink film

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie is 31 years old, married, and has 4 children who are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Julie has a fishing business in the Philippines. Julie has requested a PHP 21000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing nets and other fishing equipment.

Julie has been in this business for 12 years. In the future, Julie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en: Jovelyn is a micro-finance member of PMPC. She is 23 years old and married with 1 infant child. She lives in Bitaug, Enrique Villanueva, Siquijor. She has engaged in making viands and barbecue for sale for 3 years with monthly earnings of PHP 3,000.  She took a loan from PMPC to purchase meat and additional kitchen utensils to be used for the business. She wants to use the profit to invest more in the business and to save for her child.

loans.use: to purchase meat and kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is forty years old and she lives in her own house with her life partner and their children. She sells fruits and vegetables such as potatoes, tomatoes, onions, and other items. She has been engaged in this activity for three years and she has gained a lot of experience in retailing. She has many customers because people prefer her, as she always has what they need, because she sells quality products at affordable prices, and because she offers good service, constantly focused on customers’ needs. 

Mary is a determined and tenacious woman with a great desire to progress in life. She is working very hard to achieve her goal, and just like every good retailer she wants to expand her activity now that there has been an increase in the requests, but she needs money. For this reason she is requesting a loan from Yehu in order to buy tomatoes, onions, potatoes, cabbages, kale and other products. Mary grants she will be able to repay her loan according to schedule. She hopes she will succeed in granting a better standard of living to her family.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, onions, potatoes, cabbages, kale and other products.

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en:
Ms. Kalsoom is a vigorous, married woman. She has been doing business of hand-embroidery for the past five years. She is passionate about her work, and client demand is strong. Her husband's income Is insufficient for the family of 8 members but Kalsoom’s pattern embroidery is helping the household to earn crucial extra money and give the family a sigh of relief.

She is a mother of 6 children. She wants to grow her business. She has requested a loan of Rs 30000 to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins, and pearls in large quantities to meet the increasing demand. With the profit earned, Kalsoom is aiming to keep her children in reach of education, health and better facilities.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
This is Adelaida,39, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines.  She, together with her partner, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Adelaida maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on for their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Adelaida hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to have a good life for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise products needed in her business.

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia has enjoyed her work of making ‘Gol Gappe’ for 8 years. It is a popular street food dish in a country like Pakistan. It is a round, hollow puri, fried crisp and filled with a mixture of water, tamarind, chili, chaat  masala, potato, onion and chickpeas. It is small enough to fit completely into one's mouth. She makes it on a daily basis and has become famous in her town. 

She is married and has 4 children. She supports her husband and prepares all the products at home, once the ingredients are brought from the market by her husband. Now she requested a loan of Rs 35,000 PKR to buy ingredients in bulk, such as semolina, plain refined flour, baking soda and oil to meet the increasing demand for her product. She hopes to earn more profits and will use the profit for her children’s education, better health and food.

loans.use: to buy ingredients in bulk such as semolina, plain refined flour, baking soda and oil.

loans.name: Lozi

texts.en:
40-year-old Lozi has very good references from her neighbours and friends. She lives with her three children so she has to work hard to support them. She has been earning her living selling clothing of all types for men, women, and children door to door. She is grateful for the previous loan given which helped her increase her inventory.

So that she can continue, Lozi needs a new loan to buy more clothing. By buying wholesale, she can get lower prices. She is seeking a loan from Yehu to make these purchases and hopes they will result in more money to take home and more financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Raqia

texts.en:
Ruqia is mother of seven children, Current inflation late forced her to start earning herself four years ago. She is striving hard to meet their demands, including food, clothing, and health. Her husband's income is insufficient, so Ruqai started sewing in her home to contribute in the family income.

She has requested a loan of Rs 15,000 to buy stock of threads of different colors, buttons, needles, etc. so then she will be able to meet the demands of her customers without fail. 

She hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: To buy stock of threads of different colors, buttons, needles, etc

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mai was born in 1959. She has two children. Her daughter has gotten married. Her son is a worker. Her husband is dead. 

She has a farm where she raises chickens, feeds fish, and grows vegetable for a living. Her family’s total earnings are about 6,000,000 VND per month. 
She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2004. In the last cycle she borrowed 7,630,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,938,000 VND to buy more chickens for raising on her farm. She always wants to buy some more furniture for her little house.

loans.use: to buy more chickens for raising on her farm.

loans.name: Rizalyn

texts.en: Rizalyn is a member of PMPC under the micro-finance program. She is 39 years of age, married with 4 school-age children, and a resident of Bitaug, Enrique Villanueva, Siquijor.  She has engaged in making and selling rice cakes for 2 years with earnings of PHP 2,000 average a month.  She decided to access a loan in PMPC to purchase raw ingredients to make rice cakes.  With God's help, she hopes to improve the living standard of the family and support the educational needs of her children.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make rice cakes

loans.name: Nasira

texts.en:
Nasira is married and the mother of four children. She is a sober yet hardworking lady. Her husband is employed, but with the current inflation rate, the money coming into the house becomes insufficient for the family members. So Nasira is providing a helping hand for her husband and hence supporting the family. She started her business to contribute to the family income. At present, she enjoys a great client list and has gained a lot of appreciation and popularity in her community. 

She requested a loan of 10,000 Pakistan rupees to buy stock of threads of different colors, buttons, needles, etc., so that she would be able to meet the demands of her customers without fail. 

She hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: to buy stock of threads of different colors, buttons, needles, etc.

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en: Asuncion is a 49-year-old married mom of three children. She lives in Carangan, Ozamis City, in the Philippines. Asuncion has been sewing for six years, designing custom dresses according to each customer's desired style, and sometimes she creates designs out of her own will and imagination. Every month, Asuncion earns 5,000 PHP. She joined Gata Daku MPC, her local loan cooperative, earlier this year. She has applied for a loan of 7,000 PHP from the cooperative to buy sewing materials such as textiles and thread. In the future, Asuncion plans to expand her business and/or buy another set of sewing machines.

loans.use: to buy sewing materials such as textiles and thread.

loans.name: Ma. Cristina

texts.en:
This is Ma. Cristina, 33, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Raymar and a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their own household while operating their business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ma. Cristina has a house for rent. She also has a watch-repair business managed by her and her husband. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 9,000 in sales monthly.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan for the repair and maintenance of her house for rent. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Ma. Cristina dreams to give her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for repairs and maintenance of her house for rent.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia started a  Gol Gappy business with her husband 5 years ago. It is a popular food dish of the subcontinent. It is a round, hollow puri, fried crisp and filled with a mixture of water, tamarind, chili, chaat  masala, potato, onion and chickpeas. It is small enough to fit completely into one's mouth.

She has 4 children. She supports her husband and prepares all the products at home, once the ingredients are brought from the market by him. Now she requested a loan of Rs 30,000 PKR to buy ingredients in bulk such as plain refined flour, semolina, baking soda and oil to meet the increasing demand for her product. She hopes to earn more profits and will use the profit for her children’s education, better health, food and well being.

loans.use: to buy ingredients in bulk such as plain refined flour, semolina, baking soda and oil.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
This is Milagros. She previously accessed a 16,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts and accessories, and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her earnings were a big help with their personal, household and business expenditures. She would like to apply for another 16,000 PHP loan for buying spare parts and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Milagros dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of their tricycle.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 39 years old and married with 8 children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery products to sell.

She has been in this business for 6 years and has previously received funds through Kiva. Mary Jane aspires to building and expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a merchant. She has two daughters. She is married, and she lives in Kisauni in Mombasa municipality.

Hellen has been making and selling doughnuts, cakes, and breads for more than two years. Her business is located in her home, and she sells her products door to door.  She thinks that her major advantage is that her products have a special flavor, and in addition to that, she is a friendly person who gets on well with other people. This helps her to make sales.

Her dream is to have a bigger bakery and her own home since they rent the place where they live. The loan that Hellen is requesting is needed to buy flour, oil, sugar, butter and other ingredients to make doughnuts, cakes, and breads. With the help of this loan, she will be able to generate earnings and cover her children's education. She will also help her husband with the financial upkeep of the household.

loans.use: to buy flour, oil, sugar, butter and other ingredients.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is 23 years old and lives with her life companion and their son. She buys and sells clothing for women and children. Jamila offers a great variety of skirts, dresses, blouses, and other items. She has been in business for one year and has gained experience in making sales. Her business is home-based, selling to the neighborhood. She has many customers who prefer to buy from her because she always has what they need at affordable prices. Her products are of high quality, but most of all, she provides good service. Jamila also manages an internet cafe where she has one employee.

She is an active woman who is dedicated to her work. She is determined and always looking for ways to get ahead. Her greatest secret is her motivation to become successful. Demand has increased in recent weeks, so she has decided to make a new investment. However, she does not have sufficient capital and has requested a loan from Yehu so that she can buy clothing in bulk. She says that she will be able to repay her debt on time and has faith that she can provide a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: to buy clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en: Shahida is a 25-year-old young, hard working, married woman. She lives in Pakistan with her husband and son. Her husband is jobless and her son is four years old. She is living in a rented house with her family. Shahida is a tailor and she is the only person in the family earning an income. Her monthly net income from her business is not sufficient to meet her high expenses and house rent. That is why, as a member of an eight-person lending group, she has requested a loan from KIVA partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase a sewing machine and clothing to grow her business. She hopes, with the help of the loan, to reach her desired net income and be able to save for their future. With the profits, she wants to purchase new furniture for her house. She dreams of giving her children a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and clothing.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children, and all go to school. She also takes care of one additional family member (her mother).
 
She has a business of poultry keeping at her home. She sells her products on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last two years. She works seven days a week.  

She has requested a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT – SACCO to buy more animal feeds, vaccines and drinking utensils. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to build another chicken house so as to expand her production. 

She lives in her own house, and the family has access to electricity but has no access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more animal feeds, vaccines and drinking utensils.

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Due to cultural reasons, Iman prefers that her photo is not on the Internet; thus, the above photo is of her husband. 

Iman is a 23-year-old married woman who has one family member. She is from Al Koorah, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 400 Jordan dinar (JD) to pay for her home improvements; she would like to buy new electronics. In the future, she wants to buy new furniture for her children.

Since Iman is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for home improvements.

loans.name: Aminah

texts.en: Aminah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children and three of her children go to school. She also takes care of one additional family member (her mother). She sells charcoal at the market. She sells her products on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last three years. She works seven days a week.  She has requested a loan of Uganda shillings 300,000 from MCDT – SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to expand her business in order to serve more customers and to become a wholesaler by going to villages for charcoal. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline has a retail shop in Ndunyu Njeru, a town in Kenya, and has run the business for two years. She is 28 years old and a single mother of two children.

This is her second loan term with KADET LTD, and she plans to use it to buy more sugar, rice, flour and cooking fat to sell in her business. With the loan, she anticipates being able to increase her income, with which she will pay school fees for her children.

In the future, Caroline hopes to grow her business and thereby improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, rice, flour and cooking fat.

loans.name: Selvia

texts.en:
Selvia is a micro-finance member of PMPC. She is 50 years old and married with six adult-age children. She lives in Sandugan, Larena, Siquijor.  

She has sold coconut wine and homemade bread for a period of one year, with an average monthly income of  2,000 Philippines pesos (Php). She decided to engage in another line of economic activity, like raising pigs, to have an additional source of income; that is why she joined PMPC to have financial access.  

She took a loan from PMPC in the amount of Php 7,000 to purchase piglets and feeds. She plans to use the profit to support family needs and to save for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feeds.

loans.name: Loc

texts.en:
Loc was born in 1983. She has two children who are little and are learning at kindergarten and primary school. Her husband is a carpenter. His income is about 4,000,000 VND per month. Loc runs a grocery store for a living and earns 3,000,000 VND a month. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month. 

Loc has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle she borrowed 5,014,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy canned food, tissue, beverages and some food items to cook and sell in her grocery store. She wants her children to continue in school until higher education and to buy some more furniture for her little house.

loans.use: to buy canned food, tissue, beverages and some food items to cook and sell in her grocery store.

loans.name: Nawal

texts.en:
Nawal is a 26-year-old married woman who has two family members. She is from Al Bayader, Amman, Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 400 Jordan dinar (JD) to pay for her home improvements. She would like to buy a new wardrobe cabinet, and in the future, she wants to buy a new home. 

Since Nawal is under 30 years old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvements.

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en:
Kadzo is 32 years old and married, and she has three children. She earns a living selling snacks and other dishes from her home.

Kadzo works a lot, especially now that the holidays are almost here, when food and beverage sales increase considerably. She considers herself to be a very hard-working and enterprising woman who struggles to provide her family with all the best. She is grateful to Yehu and Kiva for the support provided to her business. With the requested loan, she would like to buy wheat flour, baking powder, cooking oil and other ingredients needed to prepare her dishes.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, baking powder, cooking oil and other ingredients

loans.name: Madeeha

texts.en:
Ms. Madeeha is married, and had a difficult time after her husband’s business failure. She decided to work individually and to support her family for a better future. Two years ago, she began sewing shoe uppers in her house. She sews for the shoe-making factory near her house and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to the lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. 

Ms. Madeeha is currently in her second loan cycle and has borrowed Rs 30,000 from Kashf. She intends to use this loan to buy raw materials including leather, raxeen, gum for sewing, and threads of different colors to create a means of increasing revenue so she can generate a healthier source of income.

loans.use: to buy raw materials including leather, raxeen, gum for sewing, and threads of different colors

loans.name: Tahira's Group

texts.en:
Tahira, a 45-year-old hard working woman, lives in Pakistan with her husband and their children, one son and two daughters. In this picture, she is standing behind the woman in green. Tahira's husband is a taxi driver, but his income is insufficient to meet the family's needs. So Tahira tries to help him fulfill those needs by stitching clothes. She herself is a tailor, and she wants to generate more income by purchasing a new sewing machine. She will expand her business if she makes enough profit in the future to do so. 

Tahira is a member of an 8-person group and has requested a loan from KIVA partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase a sewing machine, which will help her to stitch more dresses and to satisfy the needs of her clients more professionally. She hopes, with the help of the loan, to reach her desired net income and be able to save for their future. She dreams of giving her children a quality education.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine for her business.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 37 years old. She is married to Christoper, and they are blessed with three children, aged 16, 12 and eight years. Caroline owns a retail shop, a business she started seven years ago and from which she earns a monthly income of 21,000 KES. 

She has requested a fourth loan worth 40,000 KES to purchase four bales of maize flour, five bales of wheat flour, washing detergents and packets of milk. The profit she earns will be used to purchase a shaft cutter for preparing animal's feed. 

Her dream for the future is to purchase 10 acres of land for farming as well as to educate her children to higher levels of education.

loans.use: maize flour, wheat flour, washing detergents and packets of milk

loans.name: Shirat

texts.en:
Shirat lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with no children. She also takes care of two additional family members, including a young sister. 

She sells cosmetics in a shop that she rents. She sells her products on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last two years. She doesn’t have any other additional income-generating activity. She works seven days a week.  

She has requested a loan of  300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT – SACCO to buy more cosmetics, jewelry, weaves and braids. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. 

Her goals and aspirations are to educate her sister up to the university level and also to own a fully stocked cosmetics shop. She lives in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees for her young sister and rent.

loans.use: To buy more jewelry, weaves and braids.

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar is a 50-year-old housewife. She lives with her husband, five daughters, and two sons in Punjab, Pakistan. Her husband and one son are laborers, while she has been running her own beauty salon since 2010. One daughter helps her in the business as well.
Kosar is a member of a seven-person lending group, and she has requested a loan from KIVA partner BRAC Pakistan. With the loan money, she wants to purchase some cosmetics like lipstick and beauty creams for the salon. As Eid-ul-Azah is near, she wants to increase her income by purchasing new cosmetics so that she can provide better services to more clients on this special occasion.
Kosar and her husband are very hopeful that the loan will be a lucky and productive one for their family. She is taking a third loan from BRAC, and she is very thankful to BRAC for helping her.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Ms. Sajida is a 30-year-old, vigorous widow. She has had a business doing hand-embroidery for the past six years. She is passionate about her work, and client demand is strong. 

But business challenges, combined with family expenditures, frustrate her nearly every day. Her husband died two years ago. She is a mother of two children. Her embroidery patterns are very popular on her street, and she is the best earning resource in her household. 

She wants to grow her business. She requested a loan of 20,000 Pakistan rupees (Rs) to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities to meet the increasing demand. 

She shared her dream of running a training center for girls of her village. She would teach embroidery skills so they can help her expand her business, and also earn money for themselves. She is also interested in opening her own shop in the market to display her work.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins, pearls, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy sheep and goats to sell in her husband's animal sales business.

loans.name: Ni Luh

texts.en:
Ni Luh, 47, is married and has two children. Both of the children are married and live with their own families. Ni Luh assists her husband in making money for their family by distributing ice cubes to some food stalls around her residence. She usually sells more than 100 ice cubes within a day. She uses three freezers to produce the ice cubes. 

Ni Luh realizes that she is able to utilize two unused rooms to lease out. To do so, Ni Luh needs to renovate the rooms, and therefore is requesting a loan from TLM amounting to 10,000,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR). She would like to use the loan to purchase building materials such as cement, zinc, wall paint, etc. Ni Luh believes that she could improve her family life through the loan.

loans.use: to purchase building materials such as cement, zinc, wall paint, etc.

loans.name: Yatta

texts.en:
Yatta is 34 years old and lives in Sinkor. She is single and has a child aged 14 who is in school and lives at home. For the past six years, she has been operating a table in the market where she sells many items like pepper, palm oil, salt, onion, vita, etc. She has a lot of customers, and she makes a profit.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more pepper, palm oil, salt, onion, vita and other items for her business. She plans to build a house and educate her child.

loans.use: to purchase more pepper, palm oil, salt, onion, vita and other items for her business.

loans.name: Lelith

texts.en:
Lelith is a new micro-finance member of PMPC. She is 36 years of age and married with two school-age children and one infant.  

She is residing in Banban, Siquijor, Siquijor. She has been engaged in making and selling snacks for a period of two years, earning a monthly average of 2,400 Philippines peses (Php).  

She decided to join PMPC to have financial access to support her business. She took a loan in the amount of Php 5,000 to purchase raw ingredients for making snacks. She hopes to have her own capital for the business to earn more to provide for the needs of her children.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to make snacks.

loans.name: Victo

texts.en: Victo lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children. Two of her children go to school. She rents a drug shop business in which she sells products on a retail basis. She has been in business for the last nine years. She also gets additional income from keeping poultry. She works seven days a week.  She has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT – SACCO to buy boxes of syrups, syringes, and cotton/wool. Her major business challenges are transportation, defaulters, and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations include owning a fully-stocked drug shop and building another house in which to expand her poultry business. She lives in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and running water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy boxes of syrups, syringes, and cotton/wool.

loans.name: Phanice

texts.en:
Phanice is from Kisauni, Mombasa. She is married and has four children, all of whom are attending school. She is involved in a food vending business, where she has a locale at the market.

She tells us that, with the help of her husband and her whole family, they are getting ahead with a lot of sacrifice and hard work. They try to help each other out like family so that through their work together they can get ahead and achieve a better lifestyle.

She is currently a successful small businesswoman with a large, loyal clientele, thanks to her kindness. She has proven to be a responsible and honest person.

She is requesting a loan from Yehu to add to her stock of ingredients like flour, rice, cooking oil, etc to prepare more foods to meet her customer demands.

loans.use: to add to her stock of ingredients like flour, rice, cooking oil, etc

loans.name: Elijah W.

texts.en: Elijah W., 39, attended a university, is married with two children, and lives in Kakata. His children are ages 7 and 18. For the past nine years, he has been operating a pharmacy in his community. He loves this field of business because he helps save the lives of the community members. He also renders first aid to the people of his community and he's always at their service, because there is no health care in the community. He learned this field of medicine from a medical school that he attended. He is requesting a loan to purchase drugs such as paracetamol, amoxicillin, amodiaquine, cough syrup, septrine, etc. to always have drugs at his pharmacy to serve his customers. His plan for the future is to open a clinic.

loans.use: to purchase drugs such as paracetamol, amoxicillin, amodiaquine, cough syrup, septrine, etc.

loans.name: Benkadi  A Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BENKADI A sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  GOLOKOUNA, un des villages de SIKASSO, 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution et le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
La spéculation cultivée est  le sorho  avec  DILIA  debout au milieu. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter les intrants et semences  pour entretenir  1,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 200.000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi A group are married women with an average age of 33, on average 4 children, and who all live in polygamous family settings in Golokouna, one of the villages in Sikasso, the 3rd administrative region of Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to be able to carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. This is their 2nd loan with the institution, and their previous loan has been properly repaid.

Dilia, standing in the middle of the picture, grows sorghum. She plans to use her loan to buy agricultural inputs and seeds needed for the cultivation of 1.5 hectares of farmland. After the harvest, the produce will be sold in her village and at the Sikasso market, to a clientèle composed of men and women. She expects to make an average profit of 200 000 francs per crop cycle. This profit will allow her to repay her loan and to support her husband with the daily living expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs and seeds.

loans.name: Benkadi Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BENKADI III sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans, 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  GOLOKOUNA, un des villages de SIKASSO, 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
La spéculation cultivée est le sorho  avec  SAFOURA  debout au milieu. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer le labour et les engrais  pour entretenir  1,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 190.000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the group "BENKADI III" are married women averaging 30 years of age and five children each all living in polygamous families in GOLOKOUNA, a village in SIKASSO (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are on their second loan with the institution. The past loan was indeed paid back. 

The crop grown is sorghum, as is the case with SAFOURA, who is standing in the middle of the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing and fertilizer for maintaining 1.5 hectare.

After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village and at the SIKASSO market to a customer base composed of men and women. ASSITAN plans on making an average profit of 190,000 francs CFA per planting. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and to pay for plowing

loans.name: Blankalama 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe  BLANKALAMA 3 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à KABOILA, un des village de la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec  ALIMATA 1ère à gauche, position debout sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et les semences pour entretenir  0.5 hectare. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village, au village de fachoribougou et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 65.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
Elle souhaite entretenir  cette collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’ exploiter un espace cultural encore plus grand pour mieux en tirer plus de gains.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group "BLANKALAMA 3" are married women averaging 42 years of age and four children each living for the most part in polygamous families in KABOILA, a village in the prefecture of SIKASSO (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are on their second loan with the institution. The past loan was indeed paid back. 

The crop grown is corn, as is the case with ALIMATA, who is standing first from the left in the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing and to purchase farm inputs and seeds for maintaining 0.5 hectare.

After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village of Fachoribougou and at the SIKASSO market, to a customer base composed of men and women. ALIMATA plans on making an average profit of 65,500 francs CFA per planting. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses. 

She would like to maintain this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso to farm a still larger plot of land in order to derive more profit.

loans.use: to pay for plowing and to purchase farm inputs and seeds

loans.name: Colomba 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe COLOMBA 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40ans, 4enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à KOULIBALIBOUGOU, un des villages de la commune  de KABOILA dans la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
La spéculation cultivée est le maïs avec  AMINATA 1ère à gauche  position debout sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et les semences pour entretenir  2 hectares. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 350.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.

The ten members of the group "COLOMBA 2" are married women averaging 40 years of age and four children living for the most part in polygamous families in KOULIBALIBOUGOU, a village in Commune de KABOILA, in the prefecture of SIKASSO (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are on their second loan with the institution. The past loan was indeed paid back. 

The crop grown is corn, as is the case with AMINATA, who is standing first from the left in the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing and to purchase farm inputs and seeds to maintain 2 hectares.

After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village and at the SIKASSO market to a customer base composed of men and women. AMINATA plans on making an average profit of 350,000 francs CFA per planting. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to pay for plowing and to purchase farm inputs and seeds

loans.name: Benkadi B Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BENKADI B sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 6 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à  GOLOKOUNA, un des villages de SIKASSO, 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution et le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
La spéculation cultivée est  le sorho  avec  FATOUMATA  debout au milieu. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter le labour et les engrais  pour entretenir  1,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 200.000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of Benkadi B group are married women, who average 32 years of age, with six children each, and who all live in polygamous families in Golokouna, one of the villages in Sikasso, Mali's third administrative region. 

They have been collaborating with the micro-finance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to carry on their farming activities during the winter season. They are on their second loan from the institution and the previous loan was repaid in full. 

Fatoumata, who is standing in the middle of the photo, farms sorghum. With her loan she is planning to pay for labor costs and buy fertilizers for 1.5 hectars of land. Once harvested, the crop is sold in the village and at Sikasso's market to a customer base made up of men and women.

She is expecting to make an average profit of 200,000FCFA per season. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with the daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs and seeds.

loans.name: Blankalama 4 Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe  BLANKALAMA 4 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans, 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à KABOILA, un des village de la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, le prêt passé a été bien remboursé.
La spéculation cultivée est  le maïs avec  DJARATOU  1ère à gauche, position debout sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labour, acheter des intrants et les semences pour entretenir  1hectare. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village, au village de fachoribougou et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 155.500FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.

The six members of the group "BLANKALAMA 4" are married women averaging 34 years of age and four children living for the most part in polygamous families in KABOILA, a village in the prefecture of SIKASSO (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are on their second loan with the institution. The past loan was indeed paid back. 

The crop grown is corn, as is the case with DJARATOU, who is standing first from the left in the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing and to purchase farm inputs and seeds to maintain one hectare.

After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village, at the village of Fachoribougou, and at the SIKASSO market to a customer base composed of men and women. DJARATOU plans on making an average profit of 155,000 francs CFA per planting. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to pay for plowing and to purchase farm inputs and seeds

texts.fr:

MAMINATA plans on making an average profit of 185,000 francs CFA per planting. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with day-to-day expenses.

loans.name: Colomba 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe COLOMBA 3 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39ans, 4enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à KOULIBALIBOUGOU, un des villages de la commune  de KABOILA dans la préfecture de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage.
